comments.body:
This isn't a user-facing bug but trying to import any of the ExcelWriter subclasses would exhibit rather surprising behavior which causes a test failure when getting rid of the subclassing. For instance:

```python
>>> from pandas.io.excel._openpyxl import _OpenpyxlWriter
>>> writer = _OpenpyxlWriter('foo.xlsx')
>>> type(writer)
<class 'pandas.io.excel._xlsxwriter._XlsxWriter'>
```

From the comment directly preceding this it appears this condition was backwards, so changed as such

comments.body:
Is `io.engine` ever None? Coverage here might be a little suspect for cases like:

```python
read_excel(ExcelFile(), engine='xlrd')
```

which I suppose should work fine (assuming xlrd is default) but may not be covered here explicitly
Current behaviour is `io.engine` in this line will default to 'xlrd' since that's in the ExcelFile constuctor -> added a test case to make this more explicit.

comments.body: Is BytesIO absolutely required here? Seems like we could treat str / bytes more consistently
We aren't wrapping str with an IO object so asking if that's really required for bytes

Yes I think it is needed. Probably `str` works just for filenames and not for stringified objects?

I had tried to treat `str` and `buffer` the same way, which could work with xlrd by passing the file contents to the `file_contents` kwarg in `xlrd.open_workbook` but I found no way to do the same thing in openpyxl and other engines.

And just by skipping `BytesIO`, engines complain as they try to open the thing as if it was a file:
```
File "...\xlrd\__init__.py", line 111, in open_workbook
    with open(filename, "rb") as f:
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0x91 in position 14: invalid start byte
```
and
```
openpyxl.utils.exceptions.InvalidFileException: openpyxl does not support b'.relspk\x05\x06\x00\x00\x00\x00\x1d\x00\x1d\x00\xe1\x07\x00\x00\x8f\xa9\x0e\x00\x00\x00' file format, please check you can open it with Excel first. Supported formats are: .xlsx,.xlsm,.xltx,.xltm
```
Would it make sense to make this an abstract method, and make child classes be explicit on how the close is performed (including when no close is performed)?
In an earlier version of this PR, this was an abstract method, but the powers that be preferred this.
We can't make a new abstract method in a bugfix release. Any child not implementing it would fail when the class is instantiated.

Rather than this should register the writer globally

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/120e9d9fae447be2e1cea3fd83a1f19501972cca/pandas/core/config_init.py#L576
The weird thing is that this stuff does not seem to be used anywhere. Correct me if I'm wrong. I added a similar bit for the OpenOffice file format, but it did not seem to be called/tested anywhere.
can we type this? (not sure its easy)
Out of scope for this PR I think.
sure

comments.body: `to_excel` does not take the `storage_options` argument. It would make sense to add it (`read_excel` takes this argument). Probably better to do that in a follow-up PR.
yep
I could be wrong but the +1 feels a little arbitrary here - what would happen if there were say two consecutive rows in the column with missing data?

Good point, thanks for bringing this up. Will add another test for this, but I think the +1 is ok here. It's not about handling 1 empty row, the problem was that `offset` was the line containing MI names when index names were present. `offset` is the position from which forward filling logic started, so the names were being used to forward fill missing MI values. The +1 is to make sure that `offset` points to the first line of MI values instead, so forward filling only includes actual values.
This explanation (paraphrased) would be good to include as a comment.
Added test for multiple blanks after name and a clearer comment
